Epstein-Files Declassified Documents Archive

Epstein Contact List: The Full Directory of His Network

In 2009, a housekeeper at Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach mansion discovered a battered leather address book. Inside were nearly 100 pages of names, phone numbers, and addresses—what became known as the "black book." This contact list, combined with email records, phone logs, and other documentation, reveals the breadth of Epstein's network. From heads of state to Hollywood stars, from Nobel laureates to underage girls, the contact list documents the people in Epstein's orbit.

The Black Book: Primary Source

The original black book contained:
  • Nearly 100 pages of handwritten entries
  • Multiple categories: Organized by location and relationship type
  • Direct contact information: Home numbers, cell phones, and addresses
  • Personal notes: Annotations about relationships and preferences
  • Update history: Evidence of ongoing maintenance of the list
The book was seized as evidence and copies entered the public record through litigation. It remains the primary source for understanding Epstein's network.

Categories of Contacts

The contact list reveals distinct groups within Epstein's network:
  • Political figures: Current and former elected officials from multiple countries
  • Royalty: Members of royal families, particularly British royals
  • Business leaders: CEOs, investors, and entrepreneurs
  • Scientists and academics: Prominent researchers and university figures
  • Celebrities: Actors, musicians, and entertainment industry figures
  • Young women: Numerous entries with first names and phone numbers
Each category represents different aspects of Epstein's operations and interests.

Notable Names in the Directory

The contact list includes many prominent individuals:
  • Donald Trump: Listed with multiple phone numbers
  • Bill Clinton: Listed with various contact methods
  • Prince Andrew: Multiple entries with different numbers
  • Ehud Barak: Former Israeli Prime Minister
  • Leslie Wexner: Victoria's Secret owner and Epstein associate
  • Alan Dershowitz: Harvard law professor who represented Epstein
Presence in the contact list indicates at minimum that Epstein had direct contact information, though it doesn't prove the nature of relationships.

The Young Women's Entries

Among the most concerning entries:
  • First names only: Many entries list only first names with phone numbers
  • Age notations: Some entries included ages, including minors
  • Location data: Schools and hometowns noted for some
  • Recruitment notes: Annotations suggesting how contacts were made
Investigative journalists have cross-referenced these entries with victim testimony and public records to identify individuals who were minors when Epstein contacted them.

Supplementary Contact Records

Beyond the black book, additional contact documentation exists:
  • Email records: Digital contacts from seized computers
  • Phone records: Call logs from Epstein's various phones
  • Staff contacts: Lists of household employees and their duties
  • Business associates: Professional contact lists
Together, these documents paint a comprehensive picture of Epstein's network and daily communications.
The Epstein contact list provides unprecedented insight into the network of a man who cultivated relationships with the world's most powerful people. The black book and supplementary contact records document connections spanning politics, royalty, business, academia, and entertainment. While having contact information doesn't prove wrongdoing, the list establishes that Epstein had direct access to an extraordinary range of influential individuals. For investigators and journalists, the contact list has proven invaluable in understanding how Epstein operated and who might have knowledge of his activities.
